Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Theoretical Studies of the Relationships between Bonding Preferences in Inorganic Molecules, their Oligomers, and Extended Solids - focusing on Metal Halides.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kelling Donald of the University of Richmond is supported by a CAREER award from the Theory, Models and Computational Chemistry program in the Chemistry Division for computational research in pursuit of a fundamental understanding of the relationship between bonding preferences in molecules (with metal halides as the systems of choice) and the structural preferences in the oligomers and extended solids they condense to form. The overarching goal is to elucidate how molecules carry the data that allow them to decide with such amazing precision the structure type preferences of their extended solids. The set of di- and tri-halides and hydrides of the main group and d-block metals are the systems of choice for this project. This fundamental research is complimented by applied investigations of halogen bonding by metal halides and a joint theory-synthesis project that targets a novel class of sandwich complexes that exhibit bending trends analogous to the bending patterns observed in the group 2 metal dihalides.

The prediction of structure of the even simplest crystalline solids from knowledge of their chemical composition is a grand-challenge for theoretical chemistry. This research program is accomplished with the full involvement of undergraduates at all levels of the research endeavor (from conceptualization to publication). The Donald research group collaborates with the Richmond Math-Science Investigators program and area high schools to broaden the pipeline of students from underrepresented groups entering college and pursuing degrees in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This National Science Foundation grant enabled our research laboratory at the University of Richmond to make to date some 20 contributions to related areas on the frontier of structural chemistry and the chemical and materials sciences. We have employed theoretical and computational methods to demonstrate, for instance, the significance of a special kind of interaction called halogen bonding for cases that were traditionally ignored (inorganic analogues of organic compounds). Halogen bonds involve interactions between halides (i.e. atoms like chlorine, bromine or iodine) with other atoms like nitrogen or oxygen in compounds, and roles for halogen bonds have been identified in biology, where the halides are typically bonded to carbon.  We considered cases where the halides are bonded to silicon and germanium (instead of carbon) – cases that were largely unexamined. Those interactions may prove to be useful in crystal engineering and in our search for new materials involving Si and Ge halides.

We showed separately that it is more difficult than some anticipated to predict important properties of novel materials based on the properties of the pieces or individual units that make the materials. Solid water, for example, is made up of arrays of water molecules: (H2O)n where n is unimaginably large. But can we make a good guess about what ice looks like at the molecular level by extrapolating from our knowledge of water and how water clusters arrange when n is much smaller, e.g. n = 4, 5, or 6? We showed that this kind of extrapolation is relatively easy for some materials but very hard for other materials such as certain metal halides (e.g. CdF2). Simplifying the prediction of new materials is one of our ultimate goals in this project. Two publications related to this goal have been featured on covers of academic journals:

 https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/chem.201584703

and https://link.springer.com/journal/11224/26/5

Other contributions from our group have dealt with molecular machines, modeling certain chemical reactions, and identifying new ways in which atoms can come together and predicting new compounds – such as atypical planar molecules. One such publication appeared in Nature Reviews – Chemistry and was acknowledged with a graphic on the cover of the journal.

https://www.nature.com/natrevchem/volumes/2/issues/2 

We are most grateful to the national science foundation for their support for our research work.

 Broader Impact

In the past several years since the award, the grant has funded a number of outreach activities that continue to benefit the broader Richmond community. Through the College Outreach Nurturing Teens in Science (COUNTS) program, the PI has hosted some 165 students from the full spectrum of schools in the city of Richmond and surrounding counties for COUNTS seminars in the Chemistry Department at the University of Richmond. These seminars are daylong experiences for high school students (juniors primarily) who are interested in pursuing science degrees in college. Students from all backgrounds are encouraged to apply, but a primary goal of the seminar has been to expose students from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences to the offerings of a college education in the sciences, and in Chemistry in particular. The seminar engages attendees through short talks supported by hands-on science laboratory activities led by University of Richmond Chemistry faculty (the PI and colleagues) and discussions led by UR staff on academic skills, stress management, and the college admissions process. The seminars have typically been held on a Saturday in February and again in April each spring. The students who have attended this seminar report that it was helpful for them as they prepared for college and agreed overwhelmingly that the seminar exceeded their expectations. Of the seminar attendees, 22 were invited over five years to spend a summer in a research laboratory in our Chemistry department, and three of them have already appeared as co-authors on peer-reviewed publications. 

A related activity that has enhanced the experience in high school chemistry classrooms in our city and surrounding counties is a annual two day residential structure determination workshop that this grant also funded. The workshop provides opportunities for ten high school students and twenty students to spend two days (in May, each year) using the equipment in our Chemistry department to prepare or extract an ‘unknown’ compound (such as eugenol from cloves) and to determine the identity of the compounds. The attendees are treated to talks as well on spectroscopic and computational methods for identifying or confirming the structures of compounds. A number of the teachers who have attended the workshop over the years have written the PI or made time to talk in person to tell of the impact of the experience on their work and on their students. An article by the author and a colleague on the civic conscience and science education Science and Engineering Ethics (Vol. 19(3), pp 1229–1240) was published in during this grant period as well.
